item.title: Codeforces 1295D - Same GCDs
item.description: FML Solution Let $g= \gcd(a,m)$, so we have $a=g\cdot k, m=g\cdot l,\gcd(l,k)=1$,first observation is that if we want $\gcd(a,m)=\gcd(a+x,m)$, $x$ has to be a multiple of $g$, let $x=n\cdot g$. Furthermore, $k+n$ and $l$ have to be coprime, so we need to find how many numbers ranging from $k$ to $k+l$ are coprime with $l$. For numbers bigger than $l$, if $\gcd(k+x,l)=1$, then $\gcd((k+x)\bmod l,l)=1$.
